Phenolic compounds are major micronutrients in our diet,1 and evidence for their role in the prevention of degenerative diseases such as cancer, inflammation and neurodegenerative diseases is emerging. The easily destruction against environment stresses and low bioavailability of phenolics are main limitations of their application. Therefore, nano-encapsulated phenolics as a fine delivery system can solve their restrictions. Polymeric nanoparticles and natural nano-carriers are one of the most effective and industrial techniques which can be used for protection and delivery of phenolics. In this review, preparation, application and characterization of polymeric based nano-capsules and natural nano-carriers for phenolics have been considered and discussed including polymeric nanoparticles, polymeric complex nanoparticles, cyclodextrins, nano-caseins, nanocrystals, electrospun nano-fibers, electro-sprayed nanoparticles, and nano-spray dried particles. Our main goal was to cover the relevant recent studies in the past few years. Although a number of different types of polymeric and natural based nano-scale delivery systems have been developed, there are relatively poor quantitative understanding of their in vivo absorption, permeation and release. Also, performing toxicity experiments, residual solvent analysis and studying their biological fate during digestion, absorption, and excretion of polymeric nanoparticle and natural nano-carriers containing phenolics should be considered in future researches. In addition, future investigations could focus on application of phenolic nano-scale delivery systems in pharmaceuticals and functional foods.

. Introduction
Nanotechnology is rapidly expanding in the food and pharaceutical industrials [1,2]. One of the main applications of
anotechnology is nano-encapsulation of bioactive compounds for iological purposes. During nano-encapsulation process, beside ioactive protection, their bioavailability also is improved due to

There are many different bioactive compounds which are idely used for biological purposes in food and pharmaceutial industrials. Among them, phenolics are major components hich are commonly found in many different food plants and everages. Phenolics are classified into water-soluble (phenolic cids, phenyl propanoids, flavonoids, and quinones) and waternsoluble compounds (condensed tannins, lignins, and cell-wall ound hydroxycinammic acids). These compounds have variety f biological characteristics such as antioxidant, anti-cancer, antiicrobial, and many other properties [10–14]. Characteristics and lassification of phenolics are discussed in detail in our previous tudy [105].
Incorporation of pure phenolics in biological formulations s restricted by many reasons: fast release, low solubility, low ermeation, low bioavailability, and easily destruction against nvironment stresses. Designing of fine carriers by using micro or ano-encapsulation methods is necessary to overcome mentioned estrictions. There are some reviews which have covered variety f methods mainly for micro-encapsulation of phenolics [15,16]. lso, Katouzian and Jafari [107] have studied nano-encapsulation f vitamins in a comprehensive work which could be applicable to henolic compounds too.
Recently, usage of biodegradable polymeric nano-particles have een attracted the interest of many research groups in food nd pharmaceutical fields due to their favorable properties such s good biocompatibility, easy design and preparation, strucure variations and interesting bio-mimetic characters. Especially n the field of smart bioactive carriers, polymer nanoparticles an deliver bioactive compounds directly into the intended site f action. Also, there are a variety of functional biopolymers nd specialized equipment which can be used for producng of polymeric nanoparticles [17–19]. On the other hand, atural nano-carriers such as caseins and cyclodextrins have merged as attractive options for controlled bioactive systems wing to their resemblances with the extracellular matrix in the uman body and various other favorable physicochemical properies.
Targeted release and protection of phenolics is possible by ncorporating them into nanoparticles which can improve their ioavailability. Investigation of various nano-encapsulation sysems can be helpful to select an optimum delivery system of henolics in functional foods and other biological systems. We ocused on lipid based nano-encapsulation techniques for pheolics in previous review paper [105]. In this study, we have ried to summarize the literature on industrial and fine nanocale delivery systems of phenolics based on polymeric and natural ano-carriers.

2. Nano-encapsulation of phenolics with biopolymer-based technologies
2.1. Polymeric nanoparticles
Nanoparticles are defined as sub-micron solid particles, which can be used for nano-encapsulation of bioactive compounds [17]. Depending upon the method of preparation, nanoparticles, nanospheres or nano-capsules can be obtained. Nano-spheres are matrix systems in which the bioactive compounds are physically and uniformly dispersed, while nano-capsules are vesicular systems in which the bioactive compounds are confined to a cavity consisting of an inner liquid core surrounded by a polymeric membrane (Fig. 1) [17]. As shown in Table 1, biodegradable polymeric nanoparticles can be produced from proteins (such as, gelatin and milk proteins), polysaccharides (such as chitosan, sodium alginate and starch), and synthetic polymers (such as poly (d,l-lactide), poly (lactic acid) PLA, poly (d,l-glycolide), PLG, poly (lactide-co-glycolide), PLGA, and poly (cyanoacrylate) PCA) [20–24].
Two methods are commonly used for preparation of polymeric nano-particles: (i) dispersion and desolvation of the polymers, and (ii) polymerization from natural macromolecules.
Solvent evaporation as the main dispersion method is based on O/W emulsions by using a surfactant/emulsifying agent like gelatin, poly (vinyl alcohol), followed by evaporation of solvent. The solvent evaporation method can be used for the nano-encapsulation of phenolics in polymeric nanoparticles. For instance, quercetin was loaded in polymeric-nanoparticles by solvent evaporation method for improving of its poor aqueous solubility and stability in three steps: (i) poly (d,l-lactideco-glycolide) (PLGA) (as organic phase) and quercetin was dissolved in an acetone–dichloromethane mixture (ii) this mixture was emulsified with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution, (iii) the solvent in the resulted mixture was then rapidly removed by evaporation. Recovery of 92% nano-encapsulated quercetin was achieved, with the particle diameter being about 139.5 nm [25]. In another study, quercetin was incorporated into nanoparticles by using a similar technique, with a particle size of <170 nm, and encapsulation efficiency of 96.7% [26].
Curcumin has considerable neuro-protective and anti-cancer properties but is rapidly eliminated from the body. Tsai, Chien, Lin and Tsai [27] investigated the therapeutic effects of curcumin loaded into PLGA nanoparticles prepared by high-pressure emulsification-solvent evaporation method. The mean particle size and entrapment efficiency of resulting curcumin-PLGA nanoparticles were 163 nm and 46.9%, respectively. The produced nanoparticles increased retention time of curcumin in the cerebral cortex (increased by 96%) and hippocampus (increased by 83%), as enhanced the oral bioavailability of curcumin.

.3. Polymeric nano-micelles
Polymeric nano-micelles as novel delivery colloid systems can e applied for nano-encapsulation of poorly water soluble and mphiphilic phenolics (Table 1). They have a copolymer diblock tructure with hydrophilic shell and hydrophobic core (Fig. 1). here are many different hydrophobic biodegradable polymers hich can be used as core polymer such as poly (b-benzyl-lspartate), poly (dl-lactic acid), or poly (e-caprolac tone) covers f insoluble bioactive compounds. Also, non-or poorly biodegradble polymers such as polystyrene and highly hydrophobic small hain molecules such as an alkyl chain can be used as core polyers, but they are not recommended for food applications. The hell is responsible for micelle stabilization and consists chains of ydrophilic poly (N-isopropylacrylamide) and poly (alky lacrylic cid) [18,19].
Micelle formation occurs as a result of two forces. One is an ttractive force that leads to the association of molecules while he other one, a repulsive force, prevents unlimited growth of he micelles to a distinct macroscopic phase. Micelle formation f amphiphilic block copolymers is accompanied with minimizng free energy, and entropy change is generally considered the
ost important factor to form stable polymeric micelles. During he process of the entropy-driven micelle formation, the concenrations of polymers in solutions would be the most important actor. At very low concentrations, the polymers only exist as single hains. As the concentration increases to a specific value called critcal micelle concentration (CMC), polymer chains start to associate o form micelles in such a way that the hydrophobic part of the opolymer will avoid contact with the aqueous media in which the olymer is diluted. For instance, the CMC of PEO-PBLA and PNIPASt is 0.0005 ± 0.002%. The micellar size is mainly determined by he hydrophobic forces which sequester the hydrophobic chains in he core and by the excluded volume repulsion between the chains hich limits their size; a difference in the balance of these two orces in random and end modified copolymers may account for heir different size [18,19].
There are chemical and physical methods for fabrication of polyer nano-micelle. Chemical conjugation implies the formation of
covalent bond, such as an amide bond, between specific groups n the encapsulated compounds and the hydrophobic polymer of he core. Physical entrapment of bioactive compounds is generally one by the dialysis or emulsification procedure. The most comon method is through dialysis. Technically, amphiphilic block opolymers are dissolved first in organic solvents homogeneously. hese organic solvents must be miscible well with aqueous soluions. Homogeneous polymer solutions are then diluted roughly sing aqueous solutions, followed by dialysis until organic solvent s removed completely. The micelle solutions can be either freeze-

Block copolymers are dissolved in organic solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, and dichloromethane. Solvents are then evaporated to form a thin film or gel. Aqueous solutions are added at the same temperature and the mixed solutions are sonicated to form polymeric micelles. The solution is evaporated further to remove organic solvent completely [18,19].
In a study by Gong, Deng, Wu, Xiang, Wei, Li, Gao, Wang, Sun and Chen [40], curcumin-nano-micelles were prepared by onestep solid dispersion method. Briefly, curcumin and monomethyl poly (ethylene glycol)-poly (e-caprolactone) (MPEG-PCL) copolymer with different ratios were co-dissolved in dehydrated alcohol under mild stirring. Then, the solution was evaporated. During this process, homogenous co-evaporation was obtained, and curcumin was distributed in MPEG-PCL copolymer as an amorphous substance. Subsequently, the co-evaporation was performed in water at a rotary evaporator to self-assemble into micelles with curcumin encapsulated in. The curcumin-nano-micelles solution was filtered through a 0.22 m syringe filter, resulting in curcumin micelles with particle size of 10–80 nm [40]. The cellular uptake, in vitro cytotoxicity, and in vitro anti-angiogenesis effect of curcumin in the form of polymeric nano-micelles was increased compared with free curcumin. Thus, the curcumin-nano-micelles can improve antiangiogenesis and anti-tumor activity in vitro and in vivo, and may have potential applications in pulmonary carcinoma therapy [40].
Rresveratrol has also been successfully incorporated into polymeric nano-micelles [41]. The poly-caprolactone (PCL) as the hydrophobic core of the block copolymer for its good drug encapsulation ability and polyethyleneglycol (PEG) as the hydrophilic shell because of its hydrophilicity, biocompatibility, low toxicity, negligible antigenicity and immunogenicity were applied to synthesize resveratrol-loaded nano-micelles. Briefly, PEG–PCL block copolymers and a predetermined amount of resveratrol were dissolved in an aliquot of acetone. The obtained organic solution was added drop wise into 10 times volumes of distilled water under moderate stirring. The solution was put into a dialysis bag and then was immerged in the redistilled water to remove acetone thoroughly. The obtained bluish aqueous solution was filtered through a 0.22 m filter membrane to remove non-incorporated resveratrol and copolymer aggregates. Resveratrol-loaded nano-micelles were less than 100 nm, and these nanoparticles can enhance bioavailability of resveratrol [41].
3. Nano-encapsulation of phenolics by natural nano-carriers
3.1. Cyclodextrins
In pharmaceutical and food industries, cyclodextrins (CDs) as natural nao-carriers are widely applied for nano-encapsulation of many different bioactive compounds to enhance their bioavailability, stability, and other functional properties. CDs are cyclic oligosaccharides consisting of 6, 7 or 8 glucopyranose units linked by a (1–4) glycosidic bond. Naturally, CDs have three cylindrical shapes of -, -, and - CD, but - form is commonly used for encapsulation purpose (Fig. 1). Truncated cone shape of CDs, with a hydrophobic part inside and a hydrophilic external surface causes formation of inclusion complexes (ICs) with water insoluble phenolics [52,53]. Indeed, phenolics are surrounded by hydrophobic components in CDs, and could be protected from environment conditions (pH, light, oxygen, and temperature), with an improved water solubility. 4.1. Electro-spinning
Electro-spinning which is application of electricity for spinning is an efficient and novel technique for fabrication of polymer nanofibers. The basic idea of electro-spinning relates to Formhals [81] patent, describing an experimental setup for the production of polymer filaments using an electrostatic force. The schematic diagram of producing nano-fibers using electro-spinning is shown in Fig. 2A. There are some fundamental elements to fulfill the process including a high voltage supplier, a feeding pump, and a capillary tube with a pipette or needle small diameter, syringe, polymer solution, Jet, Taylor cone, and a metal collecting screen.
In electro-spinning process, the electrostatic forces results in formation of nano-fibers from the electrically charged jet of polymer solution followed by deposition onto a grounded collector. As shown in Fig. 2A, a high voltage is placed into end of the capillary tube. When the injected polymer solution is arrived into capillary tip, it’s exposed to an electric field. This induces charge on the surface of the liquid and the liquid starts to deform from the shape caused by surface tension alone. As the voltage of electric field is increased, the equilibrium of the electric forces and surface tension is destroyed, the liquid body acquires a conical shape referred to as the Taylor cone. When the electric field attains a critical value, electrical force overcomes the surface tension and the charged jet of the fluid is ejected from the tip of the Taylor cone. First jet has a straight-line motion but it’s then elongated partly by means of the “whipping instability” during its transit from the tip to the collector, also during the transition is drown as an extended fiber by electrostatic filed and then quickly solidifies by solvent evaporation. After the collision with the metal plate, nanostructured fibers are collected from the plate [82,83].
Many parameters can influence the transformation of polymer solutions into nano-fibers through electro-spinning including: (a) the solution properties such as viscosity, elasticity, conductivity, polymer concentration, molecular weight of polymer, and surface tension, (b) processing conditions such as hydrostatic pressure in the capillary tube, electric potential at the capillary tip, and the gap; distance between the tip and the collecting screen, volume feed rate, needle diameter, and (c) ambient parameters such as solution temperature, humidity, and air velocity in the electro-spinning chamber [82].
Achieving regular and controllable diameters of fibers, defectfree or defect-controllable surface of fibers, and collectable continuous single nano-fibers are three main ideal targets in production of fibers from polymers. Fiber diameter is the main parameter during the electro-spinning process, which can be influenced by several variables. metadata.abstractText: Phenolic compounds are major micronutrients in our diet,1 and evidence for their role in the prevention of degenerative diseases such as cancer, inflammation and neurodegenerative diseases is emerging. The easily destruction against environment stresses and low bioavailability of phenolics are main limitations of their application. Therefore, nano-encapsulated phenolics as a fine delivery system can solve their restrictions. Polymeric nanoparticles and natural nano-carriers are one of the most effective and industrial techniques which can be used for protection and delivery of phenolics. In this review, preparation, application and characterization of polymeric based nano-capsules and natural nano-carriers for phenolics have been considered and discussed including polymeric nanoparticles, polymeric complex nanoparticles, cyclodextrins, nano-caseins, nanocrystals, electrospun nano-fibers, electro-sprayed nanoparticles, and nano-spray dried particles. Our main goal was to cover the relevant recent studies in the past few years. Although a number of different types of polymeric and natural based nano-scale delivery systems have been developed, there are relatively poor quantitative understanding of their in vivo absorption, permeation and release. Also, performing toxicity experiments, residual solvent analysis and studying their biological fate during digestion, absorption, and excretion of polymeric nanoparticle and natural nano-carriers containing phenolics should be considered in future researches. In addition, future investigations could focus on application of phenolic nano-scale delivery systems in pharmaceuticals and functional foods. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
